titleStmt.title: Functional impairment prior to major non-cardiac surgery is associated with mortality within one year in elderly patients with gastrointestinal, gynaecological and urogenital cancer: A prospective observational cohort study

analytic.title: Functional impairment prior to major non-cardiac surgery is associated with mortality within one year in elderly patients with gastrointestinal, gynaecological and urogenital cancer: A prospective observational cohort study

biblStruct.note: Received 29 November 2016 Received in revised form 21 June 2017 Accepted 27 July 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Elderly Geriatric oncology Geriatric assessment Activities of daily living Time up and go test Surgery Cancer

p.s: To investigate the prognostic value of elements of the Geriatric Assessment, in particular the Timed Up and Go (TUG) Test and the Barthel Index of Activities of Daily Living (ADL) for one-year post-operative mortality in elderly patients with cancer.
Materials and Methods: This prospective cohort study included patients 65 years of age or older undergoing elective major surgery for cancer between June 2008 and June 2010.
Preoperative functional status was measured by the TUG Test and the Barthel Index of ADL Cognitive state was assessed by the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE).
Complications were recorded prospectively.
The degree of resection was noted.
Results: Data from 131 patients (56% women; median age, 71 years) were analysed at 1 year of follow-up.
Mortality after 1 year was 28.2%.
Twenty-nine patients (22.3%) were dependent in ADLs, and 43 (35.2%)
impaired in TUG.
Thirteen patients (10.7%) were both, dependent in ADLs and impaired in TUG.
Short-term complications after surgery occurred in 66% of patients, and major complications occurred in 29%.
Patients who were dependent in ADLs and impaired in TUG had significantly higher 1-year mortality (OR, 4.5; 95% CI, 1.21-18.25;
Lower scores on the MMSE (OR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.43-0.95;
p = 0.048) and incomplete surgical resection (OR, 3.25; 95% CI, 1.15-9.20;
p = 0.026) were independently associated with higher 1-year mortality.
Conclusion: Functional assessments, such as ADL and TUG scores, as well as mild cognitive impairment, are predictors of long-term outcome in elderly cancer patients.
Trial Registration: German Clinical Trials Register (DRKS 00005150)
Cancer is a highly prevalent disease in the elderly.
In North America and Europe, the majority of patients with solid cancer patients are 65 years or older [1,2].
Surgery alone or as part of a multimodality treatment regime is still the state of the art therapy for solid tumours [3].
Elective surgery is generally safe with low mortality rates, but perioperative mortality and morbidity in elderly patients are still higher than in younger ones [4][5][6].
Furthermore, reported overall post-operative complications are high with rates over 60% [5,7].
Traditionally, the ASA (American Association of Anesthesiology) score and risk stratification for single organ systems were the perioperative risk assessments prior to surgery [5,8,9].

It has been shown that the ASA score is not sufficient to assess the particular risks in elderly patients with cancer [5,[7][8][9][10][11]. Elements from the Geriatric Assessment (GA), in particular physical performance tests, were found to predict post-operative complications [4,9,12].

The GA was developed from pre-existing geriatric assessments to evaluate functional status, co-morbidities, mental status and nutritive state activities of elderly patients with cancer, as well as to predict the individualized risks associated with cancer surgery [4,5].
Both the International Society of Geriatric Oncology (SIOG) and the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) recommend that elderly patients with cancer undergo geriatric assessment [13,14].
The predictive value of the physical performance tests of the GA for longterm mortality has been shown in studies of elderly patients living in the community [15].
There have been few publications of long-term post-operative observations [9].

The objective of the present prospective observational cohort study, was to determine whether elements of a preoperative geriatric assessment could predict long-term mortality after major cancer surgery in elderly patients.
The study was performed as a clinical prospective observational cohort study at the Charité-University Hospital in Berlin, Germany, a tertiary medical care centre with 3200 beds.
The study was designed as a pilot study testing feasibility of conducting geriatric assessment preoperatively.
The study was conducted in compliance with the Helsinki Declaration.
The Institutional Review Board of Charité-Universitaetsmedizin Berlin approved the study (EA 2/103/07).
The study is registered at the German Clinical Trials Register (DRKS 00005150).
All participants gave their written informed consent.
From June 2008 to July 2010, all patients 65 years of age or older scheduled for surgery for gastrointestinal, urogenital or gynaecologic cancer were screened for eligibility.
Follow-up was performed 12 months after surgery.
The last follow-up visit for the last patient was completed in October 2011.

Patients were eligible if they were able to understand or read the German language, had a Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 24 points or higher and were able to provide written informed consent.
The exclusion criteria were age under 65 years, two or more concurrent carcinomas, emergency surgery, participation in another trial and insufficient knowledge of the German language.
Patients unable to give informed consent were also excluded (Fig. 1).
The ADL score was assessed by the Barthel Index [16].

The questionnaire includes 10 items measuring basic self-care abilities, such as mobility, stair climbing, transferring from bed to chair, feeding, bathing or showering and urinary and faecal continence.
Scores range from 0 to 100, with 100 indicating complete independence.
A score below 100 indicates the need for daily assistance in one or more activities and was defined as dependence in ADLs in the present study.
The Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) test by Lawton and Brody [17] assesses independent living skills.
The IADL measures eight domains of functioning in daily life, including mobility, housekeeping, domestic and leisure activities.
Historically, women were scored in all eight domains, whereas men were not scored in the domains of food preparation, housekeeping and laundering.
However, current recommendations are to assess all domains for both sexes [18].
Scores range from 0 (low function, dependent) to 8 (high function, independent).
For objective measurement of physical functioning, the TUG described by Podsiadlo and Richardson [19] was used.

The study staff, trained by a gerontologist, demonstrated how to perform the TUG and then instructed the patient to stand up, walk 3 m at his or her usual speed, turn around, walk back and sit down again.
The patients could use their walking aids.
The times needed for these activities were measured with a stop watch and noted to the nearest 0.1 s.
Freely independent patients are able to complete the test in 10 s, whereas a time greater than 30 s indicates a patient's dependency in most activities [19].
To assess cognitive, nutritional and emotional status, the MMSE, the Mini Nutritional Assessment (MNA) and the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) were used [20][21][22].
The MMSE is a widely used bedside method of assessment of cognitive impairment.
It has 30 items testing various cognitive functions, such as orientation, abstraction and visuospatial ability.
Total scores range from 0 to 30.
A score below 24 indicates cognitive impairment.
According to the study protocol, patients with an MMSE of 23 or below were not included.
The MNA is an 18-item questionnaire including appetite, weight loss and mobility, as well as measurements of mid-arm and calf circumference.
Total scores range from 0 to 30.
The MNA is divided into two parts.
A score of 12 points or more in the first part of the test indicates normal nourishment, and the test is ended.
If the score in the first part is below 12 points, the second part of the MNA is completed.
A total score under 17 indicates malnutrition, and scores from 17 to 23.5 are suspicious for malnutrition.
The short from of the GDS is a widely-used instrument for depression in the elderly.
It consists of 15 items, with total scores ranging from 0 to 15. Scores of 0-4 are considered normal, whereas higher scores are correlated with more depressive syndromes [21,23].
Demographic and clinical data were recorded at baseline.

The collected data included age, sex, co-morbidities documented by the Charlson Comorbidity Score (CCS) [24], preoperative risk assessment according to the classification of the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) [25], severity of surgery measured by the Physiological and Operative Severity Scoring system for enUmeration of Mortality and morbidity (POSSUM) [26], cancer site, metastases and grade of surgical resection.
Polypharmacy was defined as long-term home use of five or more drugs.
After the operation, the duration of hospitalization, morbidity and in-hospital mortality were recorded.
Duration of hospitalization was defined as time in the hospital after surgery.
Data on post-operative complications and morbidity were collected prospectively with the use of a predefined case report form.
They were classified according to the Clavien Scale [27].
Postoperative complications of Clavien grades 3 to 5 were defined as major complications [24,27].
Consenting patients were interviewed when they were scheduled for surgery and were asked to complete all tests and assessments within 3 days before surgery.
A dedicated trials nurse or a student doctor conducted the interview.
Data collection was purely observational.
Limitations or impairments in the geriatric assessment were not followed by appropriate interventions.
Co-treatment by geriatricians was not established at the operative ward.
Anaesthesia, surgery and perioperative treatment were carried out according to standard operating procedures in our university hospital [28].
An attempt was made to contact all patients by mail 12 months after surgery.
The patients received questionnaires, including the ADL assessments, by mail.
If a patient did not answer within 2 weeks, an attempt was made to contact the patient by telephone.
If a patient could not be contacted, the family doctor was asked about his or her survival status.
First of all, the study was designed as a feasibility study without any power calculation.
Death within 1 year after surgery was the primary end point.
The patients were divided into two groups: 'no or one impairment 'and 'combined impairment'.
Survival was analysed by Kaplan-Meier curves.
To identify risk factors for 1-year survival, univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were performed.
The total scores were dichotomized as follows, according to previously used cut-offs [7,12]:
• ADL, 100 'independent' vs. b 100 'dependent' [12]; • IADL, 8 'independent' vs. b8 'dependent' [17];

• TUG, b 10 s 'not impaired' vs. ≥10 s 'impaired'; • impairment, 'no' vs. 'any of the functional tests' (functional tests encompass TUG and ADL); • combined impairment, 'no/one' vs. 'combined impairment in TUG and ADL'; • GDS, 0-4 'not depressed' vs. N4 'depressed'; [23] • MNA, 'normal/risk for malnutrition' vs. 'malnutrition'; • ASA, 1/2 'normal/mild' vs. 3 'severe' and • severity of surgery, 1/2 'mild'/'moderate' vs. 3 'severe'.

Those variables which best predicted mortality in univariate analysis (p b 0.05), together with clinically important variables such as age, sex, ASA score, cancer site and metastases, were included in a multiple logistic regression analysis to identify independent predictors of death within 1 year.

In order to avoid overfitting of the logistic regression we applied a 10-fold cross-validation procedure with the following characteristics: we selected those features in the repeated backward feature selections, which arose at least six times and had a correlation which each other of ≤ 0.5 in the validations.
With the obtained features, we constructed a new (validated) regression model.
With respect to the primary endpoint mortality the following features resulted: metastases no vs.
yes, dependency none/any vs combined, resection grade R0 vs R1/R2, MMSE per point.
Concato and Feinstein [29] stated when the ratio of events to the number of covariates in logistic regression is b10-20, the algebraic model leads to imprecise or spurious results.
A backward stepwise selection method was applied to identify the most important factors contributing to mortality.
Because of the small number of in-hospital deaths, perioperative mortality was analysed descriptively.
Categorical variables are presented as numbers and percentages.
Continuous variables are presented as mean and standard deviation (SD) and, when not normally distributed, as median (interquartile range, IQR).
For categorical variables, differences between two independent groups were examined by χ 2 -test, respectively Fisher's exact test.

Differences between two independent groups were evaluated by Student's t-test for normally distributed continuous variables and by the Mann-Whitney U test for continuous non-normally distributed variables.
A p-value b0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.
All statistical tests were two-sided.
Statistical analyses were performed with SPSS software, version 20.0 (SPSS, Chicago, IL, USA).
Data from 131 patients were analysed.
The outline of patient recruitment and follow-up is shown in Fig. 1.
The median age of the patients was 71 years (1st and 3rd quartiles, 68 and 75).
There were more women (56%) than men (44%).
The main tumour site was the upper gastrointestinal tract (41.3%), followed by colorectal (25.2%), gynaecological (26.7%) and urogenital (6.9%) cancers.
Twenty-nine patients (22.3%) were dependent in ADLs and 43 (35.2%)
showed an impaired TUG.
Thirteen patients (10.7%) were dependent in ADLs and impaired in TUG.
Demographic, clinical and outcome data for all patients are provided in Table 1.
Eighty-six patients (65.6%) had at least one complication during the hospital stay, including 38 (29.0%) with at least one major complication (Clavien grade ≥3).
One patient (0.7%) died in the hospital (Clavien grade 5).

Patients with a combined impairment in ADL and TUG stayed significantly longer in hospital (15 (12;28) vs 13 (9;18) days, p = 0.004) and had a higher mortality after one year (61.5% vs 24.0%; p = 0.009).
Overall mortality after 1 year was 28.2% (n = 37).
Six patients (4.5%) died within 30 days after the operation.
Patients with a combined impairment had a significantly lower survival rate than patients with any or a single impairment (log rank p = 0.008).
Kaplan-Meier survival curves are provided in Fig. 2.
Preoperatively, 1-year survivors had a lower burden of comorbidities (p = 0.03) and showed significantly less frequent combined impairment in ADL and TUG (p = 0.01) (Table 2).
Major complications and severity of surgery were significantly associated with non-survival (p = 0.03 and p = 0.047).
Presence of metastases (p = 0.01) and incomplete resections of the tumour were also associated with nonsurvival (p b 0.01) (Table 2).
There was no significant relationship between age and mortality (p = 0.38).
Dependency in ADL (p = 0.20) or IADL (p = 0.56) or an impaired TUG (p = 0.13) were not associated with 1-year mortality in univariable analysis.
However, combined impairment in both ADLs and TUG was significantly associated with 1-year mortality (OR, 4.85; 95% CI, 1.47-16.12;
Further data are provided in Table 3.

div.head: Multivariable Logistic Regression Analysis of Long-term Mortality

p.s: A valid multivariable logistic regression analysis for the endpoint of 1-year mortality (no vs. yes) was built as described in the statistical section.
Following variables were included: metastases no vs.
yes, dependency none/any vs combined, resection grade R0 vs R1/R2, MMSE per point.
The analysis found that combined impairment in ADL and TUG (OR, 4.52; CI, 95%, 1.21-18.25);
p = 0.034), incomplete surgical resection (OR, 3.25; 95% CI, 1.15-9.20;
p = 0.026) and a lower MMSE score (OR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.43-0.95;
p = 0.0048) were predictive of 1-year mortality (Table 4).
Duration of hospitalization after surgery for all patients ranged from 2 to 144 days, with a median of 13 days (1st and 3rd quartiles, 8 and 15).
Patients with combined impairment and non-survivors had a significantly longer length of stay (Tables 1 and 2).
The principal finding of the present study is that impairment in both ADL and Timed up and go-test is predictive of death within 1 year after cancer surgery.
The predictive value of the functional test of the GA for long-term mortality has been shown in studies of elderly patients living in the community [15].
Robinson et al. [9] described the association between a slower TUG test result and post-operative morbidity and mortality in patients undergoing colorectal and cardiac surgery.
We have shown that functional impairment is independently predictive of long-term mortality in elderly cancer patients undergoing not only colorectal but also major abdominal surgery.
Importantly, these results were independent from the grade of tumour resection.
Complete or incomplete resection is one of the main predictors of 1-year survival in cancer patients, as shown in this study and in previous published studies [30,31].
ADL and TUG measure different aspects of dependency or impairment.
It is necessary to use both a self-reported and a performancebased instrument, as shown in other studies [32].
Performance-based instruments may detect physical impairment and functional limitation better than self-reported questionnaires.
Patients may overestimate their abilities in self-reported assessments.
Self-reported ADL may be sufficiently accurate for assessing later stages of disability [32].
Many patients who were impaired according to one functional test also showed disabilities in daily activities or cognition [9].
The association between cognitive impairment and adverse postoperative outcome has been described earlier [33,34].
Typically, an MMSE score b 24 is the threshold for cognitive impairment, but O'Bryant et al. [35] found an MMSE score b 27 predictive of a future dementia.
In the preselected study population of the present study, all patients had an MMSE score of 24 or higher.
Nevertheless, the MMSE per point was also predictive of higher 1-year mortality.
Overall, post-operative morbidity was high, with 66% of the patients having at least one post-operative complication.

Reported complication rates range from 30% to 50% after major abdominal surgery and from 20% to 30% after colorectal surgery [4,5,36], but delirium and wound dehiscence are often not counted correctly [5].
Complication rates after elective cancer surgery in elderly patients comparable to the rates found in this study are described in the literature [5,7].
Kristjansson et al. reported morbidity rates as high as those in this study in a cohort consisting only of patients with colorectal cancer [37].
Despite the high rate of complications in our study, the survival rate after 1 year was high at 71.8%.
The majority of the survivors lived at home.

Our study confirms the results of previous studies showing that functional fitness of patients might be superior to chronological age and traditionally used assessments such as ASA score as a predictive factor for short-term post-operative morbidity and long-term postoperative outcome [9].

Providing preoperative rehabilitation to improve gait speed, balance and mobility in patients with a slow timed up-andgo may decrease their perioperative risk and improve postoperative outcome in elderly patients [9].
However, the studies are inconclusive [38].
Since no interventions have been carried out, we cannot conclude conclusively that preoperative improvements would have been associated with an improved outcome.
Several limitations need to be considered when interpreting the findings of this study.
First, the sample size of the present study is small.
The study was designed as a feasibility study without any power calculation.
This could lead to spurious resultsparticular in the logistic regression analyses.
Nevertheless, several studies have shown that physical performance has a highly predictive value on postoperative outcome in elderly patients [39].
Second, there is a possible selection bias, if patients included in the study might have had fewer co-morbidities and better physical status than patients who refused to participate.
Further, the causes of death were not registered.

In addition, because patients with an MMSE ≤23 were excluded, the study population might not be representative of all geriatric patients with cancer, since poor cognitive function is thought to be strongly associated with, and a possible predictor of, the first signs of functional dependence [40].
Only two patients (b1%) were excluded because of an MMSE ≤23, but it is not clear how many of the patients who refused to participate might have had a low MMSE.

Conducting a geriatric assessment and an extensive interview on the day before surgery is very timeconsuming and even exhausting, so that weaker patients were especially likely to refuse to participate.
Surgery is still the main therapy for solid tumours.
The decision on whether to operate on older patients with cancer still depends on the subjective judgement of the surgeon, and chronological age is considered relevant.
However, numerous studies have shown that age alone is not a reliable criterion for selection of therapy.
Better preoperative functional and cognitive performance is correlated with fewer complications and better long-term outcome.
Performing a complete geriatric assessment prior to surgery is time-consuming.
Easily administered tests such as TUG and ADL can identify potentially modifiable variables influencing the outcome of therapy.

div.head: Disclosures and Conflict of Interest Statements

p.s: The authors have no conflicts of interest to disclose.
